title: 106_hr4924
content: The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote congressional oversight for rule compliance, and enhance accountability of Congress and agencies to the public. The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "economically significant rule," and "independent evaluation." The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "economically significant rule," and "independent evaluation," which involves evaluating an agency's data, methodology, and assumptions for a rule, including strengths and weaknesses and their implications for the rulemaking. The Act defines key terms related to rule evaluation. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the rule to the relevant committees within 180 days of the request, providing an independent evaluation. The Comptroller General conducts an independent evaluation of economically significant rules, including analyzing potential benefits and costs, as well as alternative approaches. The Comptroller General evaluates economically significant rules, including analyzing benefits, costs, and alternative approaches. Agencies must cooperate with the Comptroller General in carrying out this Act. The Comptroller General has discretion to prioritize and determine the number of review requests for submission. The Comptroller General evaluates economically significant rules, including benefits, costs, and alternative approaches. Agencies must cooperate with the Comptroller General in carrying out this Act, without expanding or limiting the authority of the General Accounting Office. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 annually for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The pilot project established by this Act will last for 3 years, contingent on annual appropriations meeting the specified amount. A report on the project's effectiveness will be submitted to Congress before the 3-year period ends, with a recommendation on whether to permanently authorize the project. Passed the House of Representatives on July 25, 2000.
